prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: spog31389
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: spog31389 represents our "quiescent" windy SPOG, showing signs of a bar and a dusty nucleus. ALMA observations of this SPOG will be able to determine the total extent of the starforming molecular gas, and detect a molecular outflow.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The two main science goals of this observation (which the correlator has been set up for) are to image the CO(3-2) emission and to detect the 870um continuum. Our chosen band for the CO(3-2) line is broad (1700km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectra averaging to 7km/s, which is smaller than the requested 10km/s resolution across the line. This allows for sufficient resolution and bandwidth to allow for a baseline in the band to be taken, and to detect and resolve different velocity structures should the line have a complex spatial distribution. All other correlator bands are set to detect 870um continuum emission - this is done to ensure a maximal detection of the Rayleigh Jeans tail of the dust continuum, which we intend to use to accurately determine the star formation rate from SED fitting.

At the distance of spog31389, 0.2" corresponds to a bit less than 1kpc resolution. Given the compactness of the molecular gas disks in NGC1266 (our quintessential SPOG) and NGC1377 (another quiet quencher; Aalto et al. 2012), it is likely that spog31389 will also have a compact molecular disk. Given it is important for ALMA to resolve these objects, the 1kpc scale has been chosen to ensure we are able to map the kinematics and either resolve the object, or gain important information about how unusually compact the molecular gas in the SPOG is. The maximum resolved structure of 10" was chosen to correspond to the optical light radius of the galaxy.
REFERENCES: Aalto, S., et al. 2012, A&A, 546, 68

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of spog31389 from the IRAM 30m, and has a total line flux of 2.39 Jy km/s (the object was unresolved), and linewidth of 200km/s. We assumed that the molecular gas was concentracted in a face-on disk with radius of 1kpc (0.30"), using this to calculate the brightness temperature of the CO(1-0) emission across the disk. From this, we assumed that the temperature ratio between CO(1-0)/CO(3-2) was 2 (Wilson et al. 2008) to calculate the brightness temperature expected in the CO(3-2) line. From this, we requested at least a signal-to-noise ratio of 3 per 10km/s channels (of 629 mK) to allow us to differentiate between different kinematic sub-components, should this SPOG have a lot of sub-structure to its kinematic distribution. This choice of sensitivity should also allow us to map bright (10% of peak flux; Alatalo et al. 2011) outflow components.
Using the gas mass from CO (Bolatto et al. 2013), and a gas-to-dust ratio of 100 (Sandstrom et al. 2013), we then use the predicted dust mass to infer an 870um continuum flux (Rowan-Robinson 1990) of 2.3mJy. Our line sensitivity requirements thus mean we should detect 870um with a signal-to-noise of 26.
REFERENCES: Alatalo, K., et al. 2011, ApJ, 735, 88 Bolatto, A.D., Wolfire, M. & Leroy, A.K. 2013, ARA&A, 51, 207 Rowan-Robinson, M. 1990, The Interstellar Medium in Galaxies, 161, 121 Sandstrom, K.M., et al. 2013, ApJ, 777, 5 Wilson, C.D., et al. 2008, ApJS, 178, 189

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: spog91676
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: spog91676 represents our strongly interacting windy SPOG, showing signs of a a coalescing nucleus and two tidal tails. ALMA observations of this SPOG will be able to determine the total extent of the starforming molecular gas, and detect a molecular outflow.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The two main science goals of this observation (which the correlator has been set up for) are to image the CO(3-2) emission and to detect the 870um continuum. Our chosen band for the CO(3-2) line is broad (1800km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectra averaging to 7km/s, which is smaller than the requested 15km/s resolution across the line. This allows for sufficient resolution and bandwidth to allow for a baseline in the band to be taken, and to detect and resolve different velocity structures should the line have a complex spatial distribution. All other correlator bands are set to detect 870um continuum emission - this is done to ensure a maximal detection of the Rayleigh Jeans tail of the dust continuum, which we intend to use to accurately determine the star formation rate from SED fitting.

At the distance of spog91676, 0.2" corresponds to about half a kiloparsec resolution. Given the compactness of the molecular gas disks in NGC1266 (our quintessential SPOG) and NGC1377 (another quiet quencher; Aalto et al. 2012), as well as many FIR-bright ULIRGs (Diaz-Santos et al. 2010), it is possible that spog91676 will also have a compact molecular disk. Given it is important for ALMA to resolve these objects, this scale has been chosen to ensure we are able to map the kinematics and either resolve the object, or gain important information about how unusually compact the molecular gas in the SPOG is. The maximum resolved structure of 12" was chosen to correspond to the FWHM of the CARMA beam, which showed the molecular gas to be unresolved.
REFERENCES: Aalto, S., et al. 2012, A&A, 546, 68 Diaz-Santos, T., et al. 2010, ApJ, 723, 993

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of spog91676 from CARMA, and has a total line flux of 11.60 Jy km/s (the object was unresolved in the 12" CARMA beam) and linewidth of 800km/s. We assumed that the molecular gas was concentracted in a face-on disk with radius of 1kpc (0.43" at the source), using this to calculate the brightness temperature of the CO(1-0) emission across the disk. From this, we assumed that the temperature ratio between CO(1-0)/CO(3-2) was 2 (Wilson et al. 2008) to calculate the brightness temperature expected in the CO(3-2) line. From this, we requested at least a signal-to-noise ratio of 3 per 15km/s channels (of 375mK) to allow us to differentiate between different kinematic sub-components, should this SPOG have a lot of sub-structure to its kinematic distribution. This choice of sensitivity should also allow us to map bright (10% of peak flux; Alatalo et al. 2011) outflow components.
Using the gas mass from CO (Bolatto et al. 2013), and a gas-to-dust ratio of 100 (Sandstrom et al. 2013), we then use the predicted dust mass to infer an 870um continuum flux (Rowan-Robinson 1990) of 10.2mJy. Our line sensitivity requirements thus mean we should detect 870um with a signal-to-noise of 242.
REFERENCES: Alatalo, K., et al. 2011, ApJ, 735, 88 Bolatto, A.D., Wolfire, M. & Leroy, A.K. 2013, ARA&A, 51, 207 Rowan-Robinson, M. 1990, The Interstellar Medium in Galaxies, 161, 121 Sandstrom, K.M., et al. 2013, ApJ, 777, 5 Wilson, C.D., et al. 2008, ApJS, 178, 189

The two main science goals of this observation (which the correlator has been set up for) are to image the CO(3-2) emission and to detect the 870um continuum. Our chosen band for the CO(3-2) line is broad (1800km/s bandwidth), but also includes spectra averaging to 7km/s, which is smaller than the requested 10km/s resolution across the line. This allows for sufficient resolution and bandwidth to allow for a baseline in the band to be taken, and to detect and resolve different velocity structures should the line have a complex spatial distribution. All other correlator bands are set to detect 870um continuum emission - this is done to ensure a maximal detection of the Rayleigh Jeans tail of the dust continuum, which we intend to use to accurately determine the star formation rate from SED fitting.

At the distance of spog20203, 0.2" corresponds to about half a kiloparsec resolution. Given the compactness of the molecular gas disks in NGC1266 (our quintessential SPOG) and NGC1377 (another quiet quencher; Aalto et al. 2012), as well as many FIR-bright ULIRGs (Diaz-Santos et al. 2010), it is quite possible that spog20203 will also have a compact molecular disk. Given it is important for ALMA to resolve these objects, this scale has been chosen to ensure we are able to map the kinematics and either resolve the object, or gain important information about how unusually compact the molecular gas in the SPOG is. The maximum resolved structure of 10" was chosen to correspond to the light radius of the galaxy.
REFERENCES: Aalto, S., et al. 2012, A&A, 546, 68 Diaz-Santos, T., et al. 2010, ApJ, 723, 993

Figure 3 shows the CO(1-0) spectrum of spog20203 from the IRAM 30m, and has a total line flux of 4.26 Jy km/s (the object was unresolved) and linewidth 420km/s. We assumed that the molecular gas was concentracted in a face-on disk with radius of 1kpc (0.49"), using this to calculate the brightness temperature of the CO(1-0) emission across the disk. From this, we assumed that the temperature ratio between CO(1-0)/CO(3-2) was 2 (Wilson et al. 2008) to calculate the brightness temperature expected in the CO(3-2) line. From this, we requested at least a signal-to-noise ratio of 3 per 10km/s channels (of 209 mK) to allow us to differentiate between different kinematic sub-components, should this SPOG have a lot of sub-structure to its kinematic distribution. This choice of sensitivity should also allow us to map bright (10% of peak flux; Alatalo et al. 2011) outflow components.
Using the gas mass from CO (Bolatto et al. 2013), and a gas-to-dust ratio of 100 (Sandstrom et al. 2013), we then use the predicted dust mass to infer an 870um continuum flux (Rowan-Robinson 1990) of 3.8mJy. Our line sensitivity requirements thus mean we should detect 870um with a signal-to-noise of 161.
REFERENCES: Alatalo, K., et al. 2011, ApJ, 735, 88 Bolatto, A.D., Wolfire, M. & Leroy, A.K. 2013, ARA&A, 51, 207 Rowan-Robinson, M. 1990, The Interstellar Medium in Galaxies, 161, 121 Sandstrom, K.M., et al. 2013, ApJ, 777, 5 Wilson, C.D., et al. 2008, ApJS, 178, 189

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The Shocked Poststarburst Galaxy Survey (SPOGS) is designed to catch galaxies during the crucial phase of star formation quenching. During this rapid transition, AGN are expected to actively expel a galaxy's molecular gas causing a move from the blue cloud to the red sequence. Recent observations of local galaxies in this transitional phase have begun to address outstanding questions associated with the quenching process, but as yet the duty cycle of this phenomenon and the range of properties present during transformation are poorly constrained.
We propose ALMA observations to simultaneously image CO(32) and 870micron cold dust continuum to measure the kinematics, spatial extent, excitation of the molecular gas and accurately quantify the remaining star formation in a pilot sample of three SPOGs detected in CO(1-0), with evidence of of NaID winds and which are morphologically distinct from one another. With these data we will be able to answer the questions: (1) What are the energetics and kinematics of the molecular gas in these windy SPOGs? (2) What is the relationship between the remnant star formation and molecular gas in SPOGs? (3) Do these SPOGs host molecular outflows?
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.0511.S, Mapping Shock Chemistry in NGC 1266: Local Example of AGN-driven Feedback, PI: K. Alatalo

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: The Carnegie Observatories, Carnegie Institution of Washington
